channel.title: Blog/Notes on Martin Proks
channel.description: Recent content in Blog/Notes on Martin Proks

item.title: Integrating Jan with opencode
item.description: This weekend I went back to test again Jan.ai for running LLM models locally on my MacBook. I do like the simple interface and already build in web-search using exa. From my crude testing I concluded MLX optimized models run faster compared to llama.cpp and I wanted to test it further with opencode. Since I haven’t found official documentation on how to integrate mlx-lm with opencode I’m providing links and settings on how to achieve it.

item.title: Trying to run local LLM on linux server
item.description:
I’ve been testing a local LLM on my trusty MacBook Pro M4 16GB using ollama. However, this configuration is limited to only smaller models with quantization usually around 4 bits. Luckily enough, I have access to a linux server with some GPUs to play with. When it comes to running LLM locally with CUDA, based on my reading the options are either ollama, vLLM or llama.cpp.

I wanted to try something new so I started first with vllm and boy oh boy, installing this was a nightmare. The latest wheels for vLLM (v0.15.1) are compiled for CUDA 13 (I have only access to CUDA 12 on the HPC). I started first with recommended approach using uv and --torch-backend=auto. After a while I am hitting the first barrier also described in issue #7785.

item.title: Time to play with LG TV
item.description: If you own a LG TV and are completely fed up with the random endless impossible to skip Youtube Ads, you have two options. Either buy the subscription, or install Youtube AdFree via WebOSBrew. To do that you have to decide between rooting your TV (voids the warranty) or enable development mode which has it’s limitations but can be a good starting point. If interested, follow the guide here. Kudos to the developers and the amazing work which allows developing and installing apps outside of LG’s operating system ecosystem.

item.title: Video transcoding
item.description:
Thought out my new year cleanup, I discovered that some of my movies in (mkv) are not discovered by Jellyfin. I’m still not quite sure what might be the cause, but it was perfect timing because I wanted to look more into ripping some movies with ffmpeg. There are plethora settings, codecs, encoders to choose from, just have a look at reddit r/ffmpeg. Below is my good enough info for now

  1. Use H.265 encoder, it’s newer, generates smaller size than H.264
  2. For sounds use it’s recommended to use AV1

or if you don’t want to deal with this, just use HandBrake which already has well predefined settings. Note for Mac users, use hardware acceleration settings in Presents -> Hardware -> H.265 (either 4k or 1080p).

item.title: Migrating Google Photos to Immich
item.description:
TL;DR: This is a summary post of my experience migrating Google Photos to immich. Did you setup your reverse-proxy correctly? Spoiler alert, I didn’t ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

  1. Navigate to Google Takeout and request all your Google Photos images. I suggest to use tar compression.
  2. Download fantastic tool immich-go, which will import all photos including metadata, albums etc.
  3. Generate an API KEY with specified permissions. For simplicity I’ve generated a key with all permissions which I’ve immediately deleted after import was finished. 
    # Import command from documentation
./immich-go upload from-google-photos \
	--server=http://10.0.0.103:2283 \ # only use hostname if you've correctly configured reverse-proxy
	--api-key=<API_KEY> \
	~/Downloads/Takeout/Google\ Photos/
  4. After successful import I’ve used shtse8/Google-Photos-Delete-Tool to delete all Google Photos, because the UI doesn’t support selecting all photos in one go. I’ve simply pasted the JS code in console and waited until all images were automatically selected and then clicked delete button.

Troubleshooting random import crashes

If like me (and many others), you haven’t properly configured your reverse-proxy, you probably experienced a random crash during importing. My initial thoughts were performance issue as described here, however the error message was hinting on something else
